title: 'Emmanuel Macron will end his presidency as he began it: alone'
summary: The decision to call early elections illustrates the president's governance, which consists of trusting only himself. After seven years of undivided reign, he is now being abandoned by his main allies, explains Le Monde's Solenn de Royer in her column.

title: Former French president Hollande says 'Macronism is over'
summary: Former president François Hollande, who is running for Parliament in the snap elections, said he has 'no scores to settle' with his former protégé Emmanuel Macron.

title: Anti-Semitism, Russia, conspiracies: The far-right candidates contradicting the RN's 'mainstreaming'
summary: Candidates nominated by the far-right Rassemblement National for the French legislative elections on June 30 and July 7 are defending positions far more extreme than party president Jordan Bardella.

title: Anti-Semitism is a poison, whether it comes from the left or the right
summary: The fact that hatred of Jews has become a major issue in the run-up to the French parliamentary election shows the extent to which the political world has lost its bearings.

title: French elections: Why will cohabitation be the likely winner (and what the hell does it mean?)
summary: In his first column for Le Monde in English on the upcoming snap elections, Le Monde's Gilles Paris looks at the previous dissolutions and the impact they had on the way France was governed.

title: Claire Andrieu, historian: 'The Front Populaire brings to mind photos and films of public jubilation'
summary: For the upcoming snap elections, France's left-wing parties have united under the name of Nouveau Front Populaire (New Popular Front). The historian revisits the memory of 1936's Front Populaire, formed out of the fear of the far-right seizing power.

title: The campaign to ban the AfD, Germany's far-right party, has been gaining momentum since the EU elections
summary: The far-right party's strong results make it a danger to democracy, say its opponents. But banning the party would take several years.

title: In Finland, the left makes a strong comeback
summary: Following their Swedish and Danish neighbors, the Finns voted in favor of the 'red and green' list led by Li Andersson, the Left Alliance's lead candidate, sweeping aside the far right in these countries, which until now seemed to have the wind in its sails.

title: Paris 2024: New material to combat voyeurism in women's sport
summary: A Japanese manufacturer has developed a material that blocks infrared photography which reveals underwear or lines of the body, producing images that are circulated on pornographic websites.

title: Football: Belgium wins 2-0 over Romania to get Euro 2024 campaign on track
summary: All four teams in Group E have three points, meaning there is all to play for in the final round of games on Wednesday.

title: France: Two Moldovans charged over coffin graffiti in Paris
summary: They are being held on charges of destruction of property and participating in 'an effort to demoralize the army to harm national defense in peacetime.'

title: 'Offices have become an ostentatious sign of wealth': Luxury coworking spaces lure in young talent
summary: Shared offices are no longer just for self-employed workers. Companies are now setting up shop in premium workspaces, complete with comfy sofas, yoga sessions, and baristas, in order to attract and retain young graduates.

title: US 2024 elections: Trump asks evangelical Christians to vote in November
summary: He also supported a new law in Louisiana requiring the Ten Commandments to be displayed in every public school classroom: 'Has anyone read the 'Thou shalt not steal' (...)? It's just incredible,' Trump said. Biden and Trump will debate on June 27 on CNN.

title: Euro 2024: Portugal breezes past Turkey and Euro knockout stage
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo and his teammates won 3-0, with Turkey conceding a comical own goal.

title: New Caledonia pro-independence group leader will be held in mainland France after being charged for riots
summary: Christian Tein, head of the pro-independence activist CCAT group, will be detained 17,000 kilometers away from the Pacific Ocean territory after being charged on Saturday over deadly riots last month, his lawyer said.

title: Iran's top court overturns rapper Toomaj Salehi's death sentence, lawyer says
summary: Salehi's lawyer said Iran's Supreme Court had ordered a retrial. Salehi was arrested during the protests that followed the death of Mahsa Amini.

title: Palestinian athletes' Olympic dreams
summary: They are weightlifters, horse riders, rowers or swimmers. Although most of them neither live nor were born in Gaza, these athletes hope to compete under the Palestinian flag at the Olympic Games. Participation, beyond the medals, is above all a political victory.

title: Barely unveiled, the National Museum of Quebec History is already controversial
summary: The project, which aims to honor 'great men' and the French language, overlooks the contribution of First Nations and other communities to the province. Some historians criticize the outdated vision of a project that is 'more political than scientific.'

title: French elections: The 'whatever it takes' school of finance
summary: Macron's camp is criticizing the left's and the far right's policy platforms, while the opposition parties accuse the government of having increased debt.

title: Le Pen's RN takes aim at dual nationals and 'French of foreign origin'
summary: Marine Le Pen and her party believe there should be several categories of French people. They intend to enshrine in the Constitution a ban on dual nationals holding certain public positions.

title: In a small eastern French town, residents fear that 'what happens elsewhere will happen here'
summary: Seloncourt, a town of 6,000, is home to a migrant reception center since 2023. But voters of the far-right Rassemblement National party talk about immigration as they fear it, rather than as they experience it.

title: In Kenya, the kingdom of marathon runners, the fight against doping intensifies
summary: Kenyan long-distance runners, stars in their own country, are in the crosshairs of the anti-doping authorities due to the growing  number of cheating cases, especially since the end of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: In Paris, Centre Pompidou is about to get renovated: 'We sought to let in as much light as possible'
summary: In an interview with 'Le Monde,' Nicolas Moreau and Hiroko Kusunoki, winners of the competition to redevelop the Parisian building, explain their project.

title: Seven New Caledonia independence activists sent to mainland France for detention
summary: The activists are linked to CCAT, a group the French government has accused of organizing the recent riots over a reform of the voter register. They will be detained 17,000 kilometers away from the Pacific Ocean territory.

title: In Great Britain, the subjects of a disenchanted kingdom through the lens of Eddie Wrey
summary: British photographer Eddie Wrey accompanied journalist Eric Albert on his farewell trip to the United Kingdom, as the country prepares to vote, like France, in general elections. From the working-class districts of Hartlepool to the prestigious Eton College in Windsor, via the seaside resort of Blackpool, his shots show England in all its disparity and growing inequality.

title: Marie-José Pérec, three-time Olympic champion: 'It took me a long time to find my way'
summary: 'I wouldn't be where I am today if...' In this series, Le Monde interviews a public figure about a decisive moment in their life. The only Frenchwoman to be a three-time Olympic athletics champion pays tribute to her grandmother, who taught her to 'keep her head up.'

title: Constitutional scholar Denis Baranger: 'The powers of government are too important to be entrusted to anyone who might not respect the rule of law'
summary: The president may retain some power to obstruct a prime minister from an opposed political bloc, but he has very few tools to prevent a government from implementing its policies, argues Baranger, a public law professor.

title: French elections: In the southern Cévennes, left-wing voters mobilize to save a stronghold
summary: Historically considered a bastion of the left, southern France's Gard department could be won by the far-right RN party in the legislative elections. In Le Vigan and the nearby towns, residents are fighting to remain a 'land of welcome.'

title: Jean Pisani-Ferry: 'The priority tasks awaiting Europe no longer align with its citizens' expectations'
summary: In his column, the economist notes the need for a radical change of pace and governance within the European Union.

title: Will our children's consumption ruin our efforts to protect the climate?
summary: Many parents trying to consume better or less are finding these attempts thwarted by the consumerist frenzy of their kids, under pressure to fit in and forge an identity.

title: German Chancellor Scholz 'concerned' about possible far-right win in France
summary: 'I hope that parties that are not Le Pen, to put it that way, are successful in the election,' Olaf Scholz told the German broadcaster ARD.

title: How Paris is adapting bus routes for the Olympics
summary: The Paris Games are expected to affect some 50 bus routes between the start of summer and the end of October. To ensure smooth traffic, part of the network has been redesigned, and tools such as traffic light coordination will be implemented.

title: Luxembourg's grand duke to start handover of power to son
summary: Grand Duke Henri announced on Sunday that he would start transferring powers to his son Guillaume in October, paving the way for his abdication.

title: 'We, the child soldiers of the People's Mujahedeen of Iran'
summary: Born in the 1980s to parents close to the Mujahedeen-e-Khalq, who waged an armed struggle against the Shah and later the Islamic Republic of Iran, three former recruits tell Le Monde about their time in this movement, which was removed from the European Union's list of terrorist organizations in 2009.

title: French elections: Feminists march as campaign in full swing on last week-end
summary: Feminist organizations marched to denounce the far right as politicians made urgent pitches, with less than a week left before voters return to polls.

title: Why Serge Klarsfeld, the renowned Nazi hunter, says he's ready to vote RN
summary: The 88-year-old, who played a major role in Holocaust remembrance and in the convictions of Nazi collaborationists, met with Marine Le Pen in February. He says that in a run-off election between her party and the left, he would vote for the far-right Rassemblement National.

title: French elections: Macron pledges 'change' and to 'act until 2027' in open letter
summary: Emmanuel Macron sought to explain his decision to call early elections in a letter published in regional newspapers. 'Yes, the way we govern must change profoundly,' he wrote.

title: Saudi says 1,301 died during intense heat at Hajj pilgrimage
summary: Temperatures in Mecca this year climbed as high as 51.8° Celsius (125° Fahrenheit), according to Saudi Arabia's national meteorological center. According to officials, the victims were mostly unregistered pilgrims.

title: Euro 2024: Hungary's Varga in 'stable condition' after serious-looking injury against Scotland
summary: Varga was taken to hospital after he collapsed to the pitch in Stuttgart, and was struggling to move after chasing a long cross into the area as Scotland goalkeeper Angus Gunn came to collect the ball. Hungary went on to win the Group A game 1-0 to stay in contention for the last 16.

title: Germany draws with Switzerland to finish top of Euro 2024 group
summary: Germany found a stoppage-time goal from substitute Niclas Füllkrug to draw 1-1 with Switzerland on Sunday.

title: Who really runs Hamas?
summary: While international attention focuses on Hamas's exiled leaders, the Islamist organization actually gets its orders from Gaza's tunnels.

title: Netanyahu says Israel is winding down its Gaza operations
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also warned Sunday that a Lebanon war could be next.
